title: Chinese Government funds and conducts 2017 Seminar on Rice Cultivation in Cote d'Ivoire
description: On 3 July 2017, the opening ceremony took place in Abidjan for a seminar on rice cultivation technology (Seminaire 2017 sur les Techniques de la Culture du Riz or 水稻技术培训班). The training course was sponsored by the Chinese Government, co-run by China's Foreign Economic Cooperation Center under the Ministry of Agriculture and Cote d'Ivoire's National Rice Development Office under the Ministry of Agriculture, and it was taught by various Chinese experts. The value of this training is unknown. The 30 Ivorian students received completion certificates on 28 July 2017.  China conducted this course in 2016 (#65981) 2018 (#66010), and 2019 (#71215).
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government funds and conducts 2017 Seminar on Rice Cultivation in Cote d'Ivoire

# Description
On 3 July 2017, the opening ceremony took place in Abidjan for a seminar on rice cultivation technology (Seminaire 2017 sur les Techniques de la Culture du Riz or 水稻技术培训班). The training course was sponsored by the Chinese Government, co-run by China's Foreign Economic Cooperation Center under the Ministry of Agriculture and Cote d'Ivoire's National Rice Development Office under the Ministry of Agriculture, and it was taught by various Chinese experts. The value of this training is unknown. The 30 Ivorian students received completion certificates on 28 July 2017.  China conducted this course in 2016 (#65981) 2018 (#66010), and 2019 (#71215).
justification: Project focuses on agricultural training and knowledge transfer without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Seminar on rice cultivation technology, agricultural training program, no direct environmental or energy components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides CFA 13.1 billion grant — via ETCA — for Grand Bassam High School Construction Project
description: In August 2016, the Chinese Ambassador to Cote d'Ivoire and the Ivorian Foreign Minister signed letters of exchange in which the Chinese Government agreed to finance the Grand Bassam High School Construction Project. Both parties signed an implementation agreement October 2, 2016. Then, on March 27, 2017 during the 3rd session on Sino-Ivorian Joint Economic, Trade, and Technical Commission, the Chinese Vice Minister of Trade and the Ivorian Minister of Foreign Affairs signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed CFA 25 billion of grant funding for two projects: CFA 13.1 billion for the Grand Bassam High School Construction Project (captured via Project ID#66062) and CFA 11.9 billion for the Ebimpé Olympic Stadium Construction Project (as captured via Project #85370).   According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the Chinese Government grant for the Grand Bassam High School Construction Project achieved a 64.3% disbursement rate. The Chinese Government disbursed CFA 8,424,194,512 in three disbursements between 2017 and 2019; a CFA 910,350,000 disbursement on October 31, 2017, a CFA 5,000,000,000 on December 31, 2018, a CFA 2,513,844,512 disbursement on October 8, 2019. The Ivorian Government also committed CFA 1,571,565,000 of counterpart funding for the Grand Bassam High School Construction Project on October 10, 2016. It ultimately disbursed CFA 1,346,132,342 between 2017 and 2022.   The Grand Bassam High School Construction Project involved the construction of a high school of excellence on the outskirts of the city of Grand-Bassam (Lycée d'excellence à Grand-bassam). More specifically, it involved the construction of housing, teaching buildings, laboratories, libraries and sports fields accommodating 1,000 students.   Jiangsu Nantong Sanjian Construction Group was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction commenced on November 23, 2017. Then, on December 4, 2017, a foundation stone laying ceremony took place and the Ivorian President named the school after himself: Alassane Ouattara High School of Excellence in Grand Bassam (Lycée d'Excellence Alassane Ouattara de Grand-Bassam). The project was completed on May 23, 2019. It received a project acceptance certificate from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) on June 13, 2019. A formal project handover ceremony took place on September 4, 2019. The AMP notes that this project was plagued by cash flow problems.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Grand Bassam School of Excellence Construction Project. The Chinese project title is 了大巴萨姆阿拉萨内·瓦塔拉精英学校 or 科特迪瓦精英学校项目 or 大巴萨姆中科友谊精英学校. The French project title is Projet de construction d'un lycée d'excellence à Grand-bassam.2. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 1120071519431. The AMP project code is 412960401.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides CFA 13.1 billion grant — via ETCA — for Grand Bassam High School Construction Project

# Description
In August 2016, the Chinese Ambassador to Cote d'Ivoire and the Ivorian Foreign Minister signed letters of exchange in which the Chinese Government agreed to finance the Grand Bassam High School Construction Project. Both parties signed an implementation agreement October 2, 2016. Then, on March 27, 2017 during the 3rd session on Sino-Ivorian Joint Economic, Trade, and Technical Commission, the Chinese Vice Minister of Trade and the Ivorian Minister of Foreign Affairs signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed CFA 25 billion of grant funding for two projects: CFA 13.1 billion for the Grand Bassam High School Construction Project (captured via Project ID#66062) and CFA 11.9 billion for the Ebimpé Olympic Stadium Construction Project (as captured via Project #85370).   According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the Chinese Government grant for the Grand Bassam High School Construction Project achieved a 64.3% disbursement rate. The Chinese Government disbursed CFA 8,424,194,512 in three disbursements between 2017 and 2019; a CFA 910,350,000 disbursement on October 31, 2017, a CFA 5,000,000,000 on December 31, 2018, a CFA 2,513,844,512 disbursement on October 8, 2019. The Ivorian Government also committed CFA 1,571,565,000 of counterpart funding for the Grand Bassam High School Construction Project on October 10, 2016. It ultimately disbursed CFA 1,346,132,342 between 2017 and 2022.   The Grand Bassam High School Construction Project involved the construction of a high school of excellence on the outskirts of the city of Grand-Bassam (Lycée d'excellence à Grand-bassam). More specifically, it involved the construction of housing, teaching buildings, laboratories, libraries and sports fields accommodating 1,000 students.   Jiangsu Nantong Sanjian Construction Group was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction commenced on November 23, 2017. Then, on December 4, 2017, a foundation stone laying ceremony took place and the Ivorian President named the school after himself: Alassane Ouattara High School of Excellence in Grand Bassam (Lycée d'Excellence Alassane Ouattara de Grand-Bassam). The project was completed on May 23, 2019. It received a project acceptance certificate from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) on June 13, 2019. A formal project handover ceremony took place on September 4, 2019. The AMP notes that this project was plagued by cash flow problems.
justification: Project is focused on education infrastructure development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of high school facilities including housing, teaching buildings, laboratories, libraries, and sports fields

title: Chinese Government dispatches 10th Agricultural Technical Assistance Mission to Cote d'Ivoire (Linked to Project ID#66174, #66171, #66160, #70502)
description: In late December 2017, Chinese and Ivorian officials signed an agreement to initiate the 10th Chinese Agricultural Technical Assistance Mission (MATAC or Mission d'Assistance Technique Agricole Chinoise) from 2018 to 2020 in Guiguidou, a rice reclamation area spanning 432 hectares near Divo in Lôh-Djiboua region. 8 experts were dispatched to carry out training workshops and research. At least four new high-yield and high-quality rice varieties were cultivated. The 10th Agricultural Technical Assistance Mission to Cote d'Ivoire also donated agricultural machinery in 2019 (as captured via Project ID#66171).   In 1995, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire launched the Guiguidou farmland water conservancy project, and in May 1997, an agricultural rice technology cooperation project was launched in which Chinese experts work in Guiguidou with Ivorian farmers to promote agriculture — especially rice farming. The MATAC teams from Liaoning International have worked with the Government Cote d'Ivoire's Agency for Rice Development and National Agency for Rural Development in 2-year-long phases (as captured via Project ID#66175, #66160, #70502). Between 1997 and 2013, 7 technical assistance missions were carried out. Each team had a mechanization expert, an agronomy expert, an interpreter, and an accountant and they lived in a ‘city’ in Guiguidou made up of dormitories, offices, experimental laboratories, and a machine repair garage.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 第10期农业技术合作项目. The French project title is Coopération technique de la riziculture de Guiguidou (DIVO) (10e phase).
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 10th Agricultural Technical Assistance Mission to Cote d'Ivoire (Linked to Project ID#66174, #66171, #66160, #70502)

# Description
In late December 2017, Chinese and Ivorian officials signed an agreement to initiate the 10th Chinese Agricultural Technical Assistance Mission (MATAC or Mission d'Assistance Technique Agricole Chinoise) from 2018 to 2020 in Guiguidou, a rice reclamation area spanning 432 hectares near Divo in Lôh-Djiboua region. 8 experts were dispatched to carry out training workshops and research. At least four new high-yield and high-quality rice varieties were cultivated. The 10th Agricultural Technical Assistance Mission to Cote d'Ivoire also donated agricultural machinery in 2019 (as captured via Project ID#66171).   In 1995, the Chinese Government and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire launched the Guiguidou farmland water conservancy project, and in May 1997, an agricultural rice technology cooperation project was launched in which Chinese experts work in Guiguidou with Ivorian farmers to promote agriculture — especially rice farming. The MATAC teams from Liaoning International have worked with the Government Cote d'Ivoire's Agency for Rice Development and National Agency for Rural Development in 2-year-long phases (as captured via Project ID#66175, #66160, #70502). Between 1997 and 2013, 7 technical assistance missions were carried out. Each team had a mechanization expert, an agronomy expert, an interpreter, and an accountant and they lived in a ‘city’ in Guiguidou made up of dormitories, offices, experimental laboratories, and a machine repair garage.
justification: Project focuses on agricultural technical assistance and capacity building without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Agricultural technical assistance mission, rice farming support, training workshops, research activities, and agricultural machinery donation

title: China donates 15 million CFA to Cote d'Ivoire Ministry of Women, Family, and Child
description: On 31 March 2017, the Chinese Ambassador donated 15 million CFA to the Ivorian Ministry of Women, Child, and Family (Ministere de la Femme, de la Famille, et de l'Enfant). How this money was spent is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China donates 15 million CFA to Cote d'Ivoire Ministry of Women, Family, and Child

# Description
On 31 March 2017, the Chinese Ambassador donated 15 million CFA to the Ivorian Ministry of Women, Child, and Family (Ministere de la Femme, de la Famille, et de l'Enfant). How this money was spent is unknown.
justification: Project is a financial donation to support social development initiatives, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation to Ministry of Women, Family, and Child for unspecified social development purposes

title: China donates vehicles to Cote d'Ivoire Police
description: On 13 November 2017, the Chinese Ambassador officially donated vehicles to Cote d'Ivoire's General Directorate of the National Police (La Direction Générale de la Police Nationale). The value of this donation and number of vehicles are unknown.

# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China donates vehicles to Cote d'Ivoire Police

On 13 November 2017, the Chinese Ambassador officially donated vehicles to Cote d'Ivoire's General Directorate of the National Police (La Direction Générale de la Police Nationale). The value of this donation and number of vehicles are unknown.
justification: Vehicle donation to police force has no clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of vehicles to national police, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 413.1 million government concessional loan for 71.5 km Odiénné-Gbéléban Road Asphalting Project (Linked to Project ID#71377)
description: On September 29, 2017, the Chinese Ambassador and the Foreign Minister of Cote d'Ivoire signed a preferential loan framework agreement for the 71.5 km Odiénné-Gbéléban Road Asphalting Project and the 61.23 km Agboville-Rubino-Céchi Road Asphalting Project. Then, on November 14, 2017, the Government of Cote d'Ivoire and China Eximbank signed an RMB 810 million (CFA 67,959,283,985) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [GCL NO. (2017) 18 TOTAL NO. (623)] to support these two road projects. The GCL was ratified by the Ivorian Council of Ministers on December 6, 2017. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. According to the Government of Cote d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), 51% of the loan proceeds (or approximately RMB 413.1 million or CFA 34,650,000,000) were used to support the 71.5 km Odiénné-Gbéléban Road Asphalting Project (as captured via Project ID#71377) and 49% of the loan proceeds (or approximately RMB 396.9 million or CFA 33,210,000,000) were used to support the 61.23 km Agboville-Rubino-Céchi Road Asphalting Project (as captured via Project ID#71375). The borrower was expected to use the loan proceeds for the 71.5 km Odiénné-Gbéléban Road Asphalting Project to finance a commercial (EPC) contract between the Ivorian Government’s Ministry of Economic Infrastructure, AGEROUTE, and China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), which was signed on September 15, 2015.  According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), China Eximbank made 6 loan disbursements (worth CFA 39,640,841,520.50) for the 71.5 km Odiénné-Gbéléban Road Asphalting Project between 2016 and 2020: a CFA 2,498,710,315 disbursement on November 21, 2016, a CFA 816,675,954 disbursement on October 31, 2017, a CFA 19,818,287,133 disbursement on April 30, 2018, a CFA 4,619,954,201 disbursement on June 30, 2019, a CFA 10,160,538,846.50 disbursement on December 31, 2019, and a CFA 1,726,675,071 disbursement on December 31, 2020.   This project involved the asphalting of a 71.5 km road from Odiénné to Gbéléban. Upon completion, this project was expected to increase trade in the ECOWAS region (in particular between Côte d'Ivoire and Guinea), revitalize agriculture at the local level, and reduce traffic accidents.   CRBC was the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was officially launched on January 25, 2016 and it had achieved a 25% completion rate as of August 1, 2017. One year later, in August 2018, 26.5 km of the 71.5km road had been completed. This project was ultimately completed on October 11, 2020. It reportedly reduced the travel time from Odiénné to Gbéléban from 4 hours to 45 minutes. However, the project did encounter some difficulties, including delayed Ivorian Government payments to CRBC, difficulties in the application of the Labor Code, and social unrest that led to work stoppages.
staff_comments: 1. The French project title is Bitumage axe Odienné-Gbeleban. The Chinese project title is 奥迭内-贝利邦公路项目 or 奥贝公路项目.2. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 1120071315079. The AMP project code is 78062000922.
combined_text:

TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title

# Description

Then, on November 14, 2017, the Government of Cote d'Ivoire and China Eximbank signed an RMB 810 million (CFA 67,959,283,985) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [GCL NO. (2017) 18 TOTAL NO. (623)] to support these two road projects. The GCL was ratified by the Ivorian Council of Ministers on December 6, 2017. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. According to the Government of Cote d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), 51% of the loan proceeds (or approximately RMB 413.1 million or CFA 34,650,000,000) were used to support the 71.5 km Odiénné-Gbéléban Road Asphalting Project (as captured via Project ID#71377) and 49% of the loan proceeds (or approximately RMB 396.9 million or CFA 33,210,000,000) were used to support the 61.23 km Agboville-Rubino-Céchi Road Asphalting Project (as captured via Project ID#71375). The borrower was expected to use the loan proceeds for the 71.5 km Odiénné-Gbéléban Road Asphalting Project to finance a commercial (EPC) contract between the Ivorian Government’s Ministry of Economic Infrastructure, AGEROUTE, and China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC), which was signed on September 15, 2015.  According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), China Eximbank made 6 loan disbursements (worth CFA 39,640,841,520.50) for the 71.5 km Odiénné-Gbéléban Road Asphalting Project between 2016 and 2020: a CFA 2,498,710,315 disbursement on November 21, 2016, a CFA 816,675,954 disbursement on October 31, 2017, a CFA 19,818,287,133 disbursement on April 30, 2018, a CFA 4,619,954,201 disbursement on June 30, 2019, a CFA 10,160,538,846.50 disbursement on December 31, 2019, and a CFA 1,726,675,071 disbursement on December 31, 2020. justification: Road infrastructure project with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 71.5 km road asphalting project, focus on trade and transportation improvements

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 396.9 million government concessional loan for 61.23 km Agboville-Rubino-Céchi Road Asphalting Project (Linked to Project ID#71375)
description: On September 29, 2017, the Chinese Ambassador and the Foreign Minister of Cote d'Ivoire signed a preferential loan framework agreement for the 71.5 km Odiénné-Gbéléban Road Asphalting Project and the 61.23 km Agboville-Rubino-Céchi Road Asphalting Project. Then, on November 14, 2017, the Government of Cote d'Ivoire and China Eximbank signed an RMB 810 million (CFA 67,959,283,985) government concessional loan (GCL) agreement [GCL NO. (2017) 18 TOTAL NO. (623)] to support these two road projects. The GCL was ratified by the Ivorian Council of Ministers on December 6, 2017. The borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. According to the Government of Cote d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), 51% of the loan proceeds (or approximately RMB 413.1 million or CFA 34.65 billion) were used to support the 71.5 km Odiénné-Gbéléban Road Asphalting Project (as captured via Project ID#71377) and 49% of the loan proceeds (or approximately RMB 396.9 million or CFA 33,210,000,000) were used to support the 61.23 km Agboville-Rubino-Céchi Road Asphalting Project (as captured via Project ID#71375). The borrower was expected to use the loan proceeds for the 61.23 km Agboville-Rubino-Céchi Road Asphalting Project to finance 92.5% of the cost of a CFA 35,902,766,613 commercial (EPC) contract between the Ivorian Government’s Ministry of Economic Infrastructure, AGEROUTE, and China Road and Bridge Corporation (CRBC). The Ivorian Government was responsible for directly financing 7.5% of the cost of the commercial contract (CFA 2,692,707,496).   According to the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), China Eximbank made 6 loan disbursements (worth CFA 30,147,872,464.50) for the 61.23 km Agboville-Rubino-Céchi Road Asphalting Project between 2018 and 2021: a CFA 3,305,288,863 disbursement on May 31, 2018, a CFA 4,465,944,824 disbursement on December 31, 2018, a CFA 6,328,424,860 disbursement on June 30, 2019, a CFA 10,160,538,846.50 disbursement on December 31, 2019, a CFA 1,726,675,071 disbursement on December 31, 2020, and a CFA 4,161,000,000 disbursement on December 31, 2021.   The project, which was originally expected to created 100 permanent jobs and 300 temporary jobs, involves the asphalting of a 61.23 km road from Agboville to Cechi via Rubino; the asphalting of a 5.5 km Ananguié ramp; the asphalting of the 3 km Rubino road; and the asphalting of the 3 km Céchi road. The ultimate purpose of the project is to facilitate economic activity between Agboville and Adzopé and the other towns in the center of Ivory Coast (Dimbokro, Yamoussoukro, Bouaké). The 61.23 km Agboville-Rubino-Céchi road is considered by a key link in the development of country’s eastern coast region because it will facilitate the delivery of agricultural products to the local markets of Agboville and Adzopé and other towns (Dimbokro, Yamoussoukro, Bouaké). The road runs parallel to a railway line and constitutes a second mode of transportation for people and goods in the area.  CRBC was the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was formally launched on September 4, 2015. However, project implementation did not commence until April 23, 2016. The project was originally scheduled for completion in April 23, 2018. However, as of October 31, 2017, the project was running 13 months behind schedule. The project had achieved a 34.14% physical completion rate as of October 31, 2017. According to the AMP, by January 6, 2021, the Rubino-Cechi section of the 61.23 km road from Agboville to Cechi was ‘accepted’ by the local authorities; however, a toll station had still not been built.
staff_comments: 1. The French project title is Projet de bitumage de la route Agboville-Rubino-Céchi. The Chinese project title is 建的科特迪瓦阿博维尔—希市沥青公路项目 or 阿博维尔—希市沥青公路项目 or 科特迪瓦阿博维尔—西市新建沥青道路项目.2. The system identification number for this project in the Government of Côte d'Ivoire’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) is 1120071324779. The AMP project code is 78062000723. 3. Additional loan disbursement details are provided on slide 9 of https://www.dropbox.com/s/8wr42j2lui4u6cn/ROUTE%20Agboville-Rubino-C%C3%A9chi_AVANCEMENT%20AU%2031%20OCTOBRE%202017.pptx?dl=0

# Title

# Description

The ultimate purpose of the project is to facilitate economic activity between Agboville and Adzopé and the other towns in the center of Ivory Coast (Dimbokro, Yamoussoukro, Bouaké). The 61.23 km Agboville-Rubino-Céchi road is considered by a key link in the development of country’s eastern coast region because it will facilitate the delivery of agricultural products to the local markets of Agboville and Adzopé and other towns (Dimbokro, Yamoussoukro, Bouaké). The road runs parallel to a railway line and constitutes a second mode of transportation for people and goods in the area.  CRBC was the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. The project was formally launched on September 4, 2015. However, project implementation did not commence until April 23, 2016. The project was originally scheduled for completion in April 23, 2018. However, as of October 31, 2017, the project was running 13 months behind schedule. The project had achieved a 34.14% physical completion rate as of October 31, 2017. According to the AMP, by January 6, 2021, the Rubino-Cechi section of the 61.23 km road from Agboville to Cechi was ‘accepted’ by the local authorities; however, a toll station had still not been built.
justification: Project focuses on road construction and asphalting without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 61.23 km road asphalting project, economic development focus, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: ICBC provides loan for San Pedro Port Extension Project
description: On November 2, 2016, Terminal Industriel Polyvalent de San Pedro S.A. (TIPSP) — a project company and wholly owned subsidiary of Snedai Energies — was locally incorporated in the Ivory Coast. Then, on May 29, 2017, TIPSP was granted a 35-year a concession by the Government of Côte d’Ivoire to design, build, finance and operate a new bulk terminal in San Pedro, Ivory Coast with the capacity to accommodate “Panamax” and "Handymax" vessels.  On April 23, 2018, Mr. Hilaire Marcel LAMIZANA, Managing Director of the Autonomous Port of San Pedro (PASP), and Mr. Chen Mi Li, Managing Director West Africa of the China Harbor Engineering Co Ltd (CHEC), signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) regarding the extension of San Pedro Port, Côte d’Ivoire’s second largest port (by tonnage). China Eximbank and ICBC reportedly competed with each other for the financing of this public-private partnership (PPP) project. The Government of Côte d’Ivoire later announced that ICBC would be the financier of the San Pedro Port Extension Project.   The purpose of the project is to expand San Pedro Port, Côte d’Ivoire’s second largest port (by tonnage). It involves dredging a basin and access channel, rehabilitating or extending the west and east dikes, constructing a container terminal and terminal access road (current cement plant road), and backfilling 150 hectares in the port area. After the commissioning of the first phase of project (initially scheduled for completion at the end of 2021), the port will allow the processing of solid and liquid bulk cargoes, including ores (including manganese, nickel, and lithium), cement products, petroleum products, and fertilizers.  CHEC is the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. A foundation stone laying ceremony took place on March 19, 2018. CHEC was then selected as the EPC contractor in June 2018. Construction began in June 2019. As of November 1, 2021, the project had achieved an 80% completion rate. 600 jobs were directly created during the construction phase, and once the port is in operation, it is expected to employ 120 people and create many more jobs indirectly in an around San Pedro.
staff_comments: 1. The French project title is Projet d'extension du port de San Pedro or Projet de construction du nouveau terminal industriel polyvalent. The Chinese project title is 圣佩德罗港口的发展 or 科特迪瓦圣佩德罗港口 or 科特迪瓦圣佩德罗港口扩建项目. 2. On April 24, 2019, Mr. Hilaire Lamizana, Director General of San Pedro Port Authority in Cote d'Ivoire, met with Mr. Lin Yichong, Chairman of CHEC, in Beijing. 3. In January 2020, the European Commission has approved the acquisition of joint control over four project companies (including TIPSP) with concessions to build or operate port terminals in West Africa by Denmark’s A.P. Møller Capital (APMC). 4. Snedai Energies is owned by Adama Bictogo, a former CIV Minister of African Integration. 5. Some sources suggest that TIPSP is a joint venture between Arise Ports and Logistics (Arise P&L) and Snedai Energies. This issue merits further investigation.6. The face value and borrowing terms of the ICBC loan are unknown. This issue merits further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
ICBC provides loan for San Pedro Port Extension Project

# Description
On November 2, 2016, Terminal Industriel Polyvalent de San Pedro S.A. (TIPSP) — a project company and wholly owned subsidiary of Snedai Energies — was locally incorporated in the Ivory Coast. Then, on May 29, 2017, TIPSP was granted a 35-year a concession by the Government of Côte d’Ivoire to design, build, finance and operate a new bulk terminal in San Pedro, Ivory Coast with the capacity to accommodate “Panamax” and "Handymax" vessels.  On April 23, 2018, Mr. Hilaire Marcel LAMIZANA, Managing Director of the Autonomous Port of San Pedro (PASP), and Mr. Chen Mi Li, Managing Director West Africa of the China Harbor Engineering Co Ltd (CHEC), signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) regarding the extension of San Pedro Port, Côte d’Ivoire’s second largest port (by tonnage). China Eximbank and ICBC reportedly competed with each other for the financing of this public-private partnership (PPP) project. The Government of Côte d’Ivoire later announced that ICBC would be the financier of the San Pedro Port Extension Project.   The purpose of the project is to expand San Pedro Port, Côte d’Ivoire’s second largest port (by tonnage). It involves dredging a basin and access channel, rehabilitating or extending the west and east dikes, constructing a container terminal and terminal access road (current cement plant road), and backfilling 150 hectares in the port area. After the commissioning of the first phase of project (initially scheduled for completion at the end of 2021), the port will allow the processing of solid and liquid bulk cargoes, including ores (including manganese, nickel, and lithium), cement products, petroleum products, and fertilizers.  CHEC is the EPC contractor responsible for implementation. A foundation stone laying ceremony took place on March 19, 2018. CHEC was then selected as the EPC contractor in June 2018. Construction began in June 2019. As of November 1, 2021, the project had achieved an 80% completion rate. 600 jobs were directly created during the construction phase, and once the port is in operation, it is expected to employ 120 people and create many more jobs indirectly in an around San Pedro.
justification: Port extension project primarily focused on transportation infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Project involves dredging, dike rehabilitation, container terminal construction, and backfilling; handles various bulk cargoes including ores, cement, petroleum products, and fertilizers

title: China Eximbank provides loan to EDIFRE for 40 Solar Farms Project
description: In 2017, China Eximbank agreed to provide a 12 million peso loan (approximately $480,000 USD) to EDIFRE, a Cuban state engineering company, for the construction of 40 solar farms in the Sancti Spirítus province, totaling 100 MW of photovoltaic installations.  The loan terms are unclear. The Electric Company of Sancti Spirítus is the contractor for this endeavor.  The known solar farms are as follows: Guane-Mantua: 4 MW Pinar 220A: 4 MW Yaguaramas: 5 MW Morón: 5 MW Miramar: 3 MW Guasimal: 4.4 MW Yaguajay: 2.2 MW Arroyo Blanco: 2.2 MW  In 2017, construction began on a 4.4 MW solar PV plant in the Guasimal, Sancti Spiritus province.  The plant was completed and officially powered "on" in March, 2018.  As of 2018, plans to install another six parks in Sancti Spíritus are in motion.   Two of these will be located in Yaguajay and Arroyo Blanco and will have an installed capacity of 2.2 MW each.
staff_comments: According to a Korean Government report on Cuba's renewable energy sector, this project is separate from the solar farms projects financed by MOFCOM and CDB in 2015, captured in project #54762 and #54761 respectively.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides loan to EDIFRE for 40 Solar Farms Project

# Description
In 2017, China Eximbank agreed to provide a 12 million peso loan (approximately $480,000 USD) to EDIFRE, a Cuban state engineering company, for the construction of 40 solar farms in the Sancti Spirítus province, totaling 100 MW of photovoltaic installations.  The loan terms are unclear. The Electric Company of Sancti Spirítus is the contractor for this endeavor.  The known solar farms are as follows: Guane-Mantua: 4 MW Pinar 220A: 4 MW Yaguaramas: 5 MW Morón: 5 MW Miramar: 3 MW Guasimal: 4.4 MW Yaguajay: 2.2 MW Arroyo Blanco: 2.2 MW  In 2017, construction began on a 4.4 MW solar PV plant in the Guasimal, Sancti Spiritus province.  The plant was completed and officially powered "on" in March, 2018.  As of 2018, plans to install another six parks in Sancti Spíritus are in motion.   Two of these will be located in Yaguajay and Arroyo Blanco and will have an installed capacity of 2.2 MW each.
justification: Primary purpose is solar power generation through multiple photovoltaic installations
evidence: Construction of 40 solar farms totaling 100 MW, specific photovoltaic installations listed, renewable energy focus

title: China Eximbank provides $60 million USD loan for Cuban 50 MW PV Module Production and Industrial Park (linked to #69403)
description: On 25 October, 2017, China Eximbank signed a framework agreement to provide a $60 million USD preferential loan for a 50 MW photovoltaic solar power generation plant in Cuba.  The equity component of this project is captured in #69403.  The PV module project is intended to improve Cuba's solar PV panel assembly plant, which will be built in the Mariel Development Zone by a joint venture of Hive Energy and SE Energy Investment Co., a UK subsidiary of Shanghai Electric Group, called Mariel Solar S.A..  This is the first renewable power plant to be 100% foreign-owned and operated  Construction of the PV module project is expected to have three installations of approximately 15MW each, and construction is expected to begin in November 2018 and be completed in December 2019.  Mariel Solar S.A. signed an agreement in 2016 for Cuba’s electric company, Union Electrica, to buy the power generated from the solar park for 25 years.
staff_comments: The Chinese name for the project is '50兆瓦光伏组件自动生产线项目和家电工业园改造项目'.This project has been coded as having Implementation status, as the Mariel Development Zone website cites Mariel Solar's SA's investment as 'in progress' (See: http://www.zedmariel.com/en/mariel-solar-sa).
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
China Eximbank provides $60 million USD loan for Cuban 50 MW PV Module Production and Industrial Park (linked to #69403)

# Description
On 25 October, 2017, China Eximbank signed a framework agreement to provide a $60 million USD preferential loan for a 50 MW photovoltaic solar power generation plant in Cuba.  The equity component of this project is captured in #69403.  The PV module project is intended to improve Cuba's solar PV panel assembly plant, which will be built in the Mariel Development Zone by a joint venture of Hive Energy and SE Energy Investment Co., a UK subsidiary of Shanghai Electric Group, called Mariel Solar S.A..  This is the first renewable power plant to be 100% foreign-owned and operated  Construction of the PV module project is expected to have three installations of approximately 15MW each, and construction is expected to begin in November 2018 and be completed in December 2019.  Mariel Solar S.A. signed an agreement in 2016 for Cuba’s electric company, Union Electrica, to buy the power generated from the solar park for 25 years.
justification: Primary purpose is solar power generation through a photovoltaic solar power plant, directly supporting renewable energy development
evidence: 50 MW photovoltaic solar power generation plant, solar PV panel assembly plant, renewable power plant, power purchase agreement for solar energy
